 JEHlEL WILLIAMS, Esq. Judge. GTPON the Petition of RUFUS FULLER V OI Kent, in said district, showing tO this Court that he is the Parent and natural Guar dian of Linus F. Fuller, Julia Ann Fuller and Rufus Fuller, Jun. all of said Kent, minors. under the age of twenty-On years, that said minors own and possess in fee-simple as ten- ants in common about twenty-tAree acres of land situated in the north part of the town Of Plymouth in LitchGeld county, which came to said minors by descent from their late mOth- CT Bede Fuller, deceased, and their grand mother Mehitable Fenn, deceased, and of about the value of seven hundred and fifty dOlars-praying for reasons in said petition set forth that an order might be passed au- thorising and empowering said Petitioner or some other suitable person to sell and convey said premises according to the statute in such case made and provided. As per Petition OF file dated May 1st 1927.

 Ordered that said Petition he continued to the l6th day of July 1927, at 12 o'clock at noon, at the Probate Office in New-Milford, when and where said Petitioner may be heard on the merits of his said Petition. And that notice of the pendency thereof be given by publishing this Order in Newspaper printed at Litchfeld weeks successiveIy at least weeks previous to said 16th day of July 1927.

dealing tn the article first. But for one, am determined not to encourage the im- por,ation or sale of it hy using it myself

 Messrs. Editors, since last addressed you, volley of Fast day Sermons has been discharged against the common enemy, and not without some effect. Some of the churches in this city, were half awaked, and, trust, that such another volley would bring them to stand upon their feet, and shake themselves from the reproach which has too long rested upon them. Let eve ry professing Christian say for himself, "I have done with ardent spirits" and the work will be half done. Let it no more be said, that such and such minister was seen to call at the bar of tavern, and tip off his glass with as good an air as the worst of us. Let it no more be said, that such and such professor may be good man, for aught we know, but he carries a red nose of his own, and we guess that, with all his religion, he would not stick at glass of brandy o, my brethren, let there be no more occasion for this reproach. Before conclude, I would say, that in my opinion there are some grocers in this city who are prepared to turn their liquor casks out of doors, and to give up the deal- ing in ardent spirits, altogether. And now, I call upon the friends of religion, the friends of their country, to look after them, and if there are any such to be found to patronize them. 5. ID.

$64,764 13

 It is worthy of remark, that more than one-flth of the entire income has been re- ceived within the last month and this ac- counts for the fact, that balance remains unexpended; there not having beon time, in tlis short interval, to employ all the means which have been furnished. The Directors express hope that they shall be able to commence the ensuing year on broader scale of operation, and do some- thing more than ever before, towards sup- plying the destitute millions of our fellow men with the word of life. The amount of expendituresis $56,522 33.

 - Debt on Societys House Cowncelled.-On SC, eral of the proceeding anniversaries the Board have adverted with some anxiety to the unpaid debt on the Society's House. Ac- cording to the last Report, this debt amount ed to S8,72O: and a pledge had been given that no part of the ordinary receipts of the Society should be applied to it's extinction. This embarrassment is now completely re- moved. A meeting of individuals friendly to Bible operations having been called few weeks since, about hundred of whom at tended, a subscription was oppened at their own suggestion, sufficient amount subscri- bed on the spot to diminish the debt one half. A committee from their number. in the course ofa few subsequent days, obtained from O. ther citizens subscription sufficient to extin guish the debt entirely. Many of them are already paid.

 By this munifcent act the Society is now left in possession of an establishment worth at least S25,OOO; where, without rent, it can carry forward it's sacred work of providing the Scriptures for our own and other lands.

 Number of Bibles printed.-Within the last ] year there have been printed at the Society's \ establishment. or are now in press, 45,5OO Bi- bles and S5,7OO Testaments. There have been purchased I'll German and Dutch Bibles,and SIS German Testaments. Total 76,7S4 which added to 5S2,9O before reported make grand total of sir hsndred Gnd nin. thonsandsir hundred and thirty-sir. printed ol purchased by the Society since its formation in 1878.

 In the last report if was announced that a set of stereotype plates were in state of pre- parAticp. These plates have since been fin 2 Ashedy and first and second edition, of 9OOO each, printed from them and seldom per. haps has . Bible of this class been more iegi DleOr complete.

THE1 Court of Probate for the District of A Litchfeld hath assigned Monday. the gath day ofinst. May, at 10 o'clock in the forenoon at the probate office, in Litchield in said dis trict, for the appointment of commissioners on .he estate of

 REUEL COGSWELL, late of Washington, in said district, deceased. represented insolvent; at which time and place all persons interested in said estate will if they see cause, attend before said court and be heard in the premises.

 By order of said court,

 RILEY COGSWELL, Erecutor, Washington, May 12, 1897. 48
NOTICE.

Scripture ought tO be prepared with par ticular reference to these Schools; and accor- dingly have directed that a sci of stereotype plates for the entire Bible, and another for the New-Testament, he cast as soon as prac- ticabDe for this important object.

 It will he remembered that a few years since the Society published some portions Ol the New-Testament in the Delaware and Mo- hawk languages. The present Report states that other portions have been translated into the Mohawk tongue by some intelligent AbO- recently forwarded to the Society ny the Rev. Wm. Case, Methodist minister in Lower Canada, and is now in press.

 4 valuable set of 8 vO. stereotype piates' ] with contents of chapters prefxed, has recent l ly been purchased of the Baltimore Bible SO- cietv, to be paid for in Bibles and Testa- ] ments.

 | Bibles issued from the DepOsitory.-During the year, there has been issued from the De- posltory S5, ,G76 Bibles and 8, ,745 Testaments. Total 71,G2l winch added, to 40, ,0l4 issu- ed in the ten proceeding years, make grand total of 51I.667. Of the issue of the last year, 53, 337 have in various ways been dispO- sed of to auxiliary and other Societies and individuals. A still greater number might have been sold, had the rules of the Society permitted sales to those who are not mem bers. The number of Bibles and Testaments gratuitously appropriated during the years, 13.286.

 Comparing these issues with those of the proceeding year, it will be seen that they are greater by 4.487; while the number printed. Is less by 4,266. It IS also observable that the number sold is greater, while the number gratuitously appropriated is less. This last fact is attributed, in the report, to two causes. I. That the Board have during the greater part oflast year, been wholly without trav- cling agents ;-cOnsequently few new Auxll- aries have been formed, to which donations of Bibles are usually made on. recognizing them as connected with the Society. 2. The Managers have hesltated whether more sparing policy in regard to such grants to Auxiliaries, ought rot to be tried. They however express their readiness, at all times when able, to make gratuitous grants where they are truly needed, and where there is known zeal in the Auxiliary to put them in circulation.

 Great complaints are again made of the want ofBibles, in different sections of our county. In one county, in the State of Del aware, 500 families are supposed to be destl- tute in North Carolina, 10000; in South Carolina, perha 3s an equal number; in GeOr- gia, and Teouessee, the same. In short, the whole Southern and Western parts of the Union are in like deplorable situation. The Society has had no travelling Agents during the past year.

 The Rev. Jonas King, late American Mis- si0nary to Palestine, is now in Paris. The Board have requested him to act as delegate of the American Bible Society to that of Pa ris on its ensuing anniversary; and also, if practicable, as Delegate to the British and Foreign Bible Society. ...

 The Report concludes as follows; {" The events of every revolving year indicate that the systems of Pagan corruption and cruelty are ere long to be broken up, and the light and principles of the Gospel to prevade eve ry kindred. and tongue, and people. But be- fore such consummatiOn is realized, much, very much, remains to he done. Not more than forty or fifty million copies of revealed truth, are yet in circulation among the eight hundred millions of the great human family.

 "While then the ultimate uniyersality of the SaviOr's cause is certain as Divine vera city can make it,-whie its onward march is smore and more rapid, (never so much SO perhaps since the ascension of it's Founder as during the past year,) yet it must not he forgotten that this cause is advanced tuTOtiSN uutlldD cuOrtSs anu tndL IncSe eUOrIS must be augmented an hundred fold before the predictions of inspiration are fulfilled. There must yet be a mightier movement on the part of Christendom than has yet been made,-there must be more and greater sa- crifces,--a more entire cOnsecration of time and talents and wealth and inAuence,-and many new helpers must be called into the field; ere this great moral conquest is a. chieved.

 "Lct then the friends of the bible, while inspired by the losses and promises here, un- l folded, go forward and diffuse this blessing at home and abroad, until it is proclaimed throughout every continent and island-that tue Kingdoms of this ,Uorld hGve become tue Kingdoms of fouv Lord and his Christ. After the report the following resolutions 1 were unanimously passed:- On motion of the Rev. Samuel Merwin, of 1 the Methodist Episcopal Church, seconded by the Rev. MT. Smith, of the Episcocopal Church, of MiddIebury, Vt.

 Resolved, That the report which has been presented by the Board of Managers, be ac- cepted, and that it be published under their direction. a"

 On motion of the Rev. MT. Eastburn, of the Episcopal Church, of this city, seconded by the Rev. Mir. Bourne, Baptist Missionary at Honduras, now on a visit to this country for his health,

WHEREAS, LAVINA WOODRUFF W of Litchfeld, in said County. has brought her petition to this Court against her husband Salmon Woodruff, now residing in parts to her unknown, therein stating, among other things, that the said Salmon, at said Litchfeld, on or about the first day of July 1928, wilfully deserted her, and ever since has continued, and still continues, his descrton. residing out of this state, in the total neglect of all the duties of the marriage covenant, on his part, to be performed, and praying for a bill of divorce from the said Salmon, as her petition on file, dated the 5th day of Februa- ry 1897. t....

 Ordered by this Court that said petition be continued to the next Term of this Court, to be holden at Litchfield, within and for said County, on the third Tuesday of August next -and that the pendency of said petition, and copy of this order, be published six weeks successively, according to the statute in such case provided, in paper printed in Litchield, called the Litch6eld County Post, and in pa per printed in New-Haven. called the COlsns- bian Register, which shall be sufficient notice to the said Salmon to appear and defend in said petition.

 By the Court.

 F. WOLCOTT, Clerk. A true Copy, 6w4S

 FREDERICK WOLCOTT. Clerk.

CHEAP AND EXPEDITIOUS TRAY

 FILLING.

trade Ii he can make nothing by it; and the grocer is willing to give up the trade, if there are no ardent spirits imported or distilled and the drunkard, even, will be willing to leave off drinking if he can't get any thing to drink. But which is most to blame, the importer, the distiller, the re- taller, or the tipler? That is the great question. And who shall stop first, is another almost as big. Now let us call our friends together, and set decanters be- fore them, and discuss these two moment uous questions. No, Messrs. Editors, we shall never do any thing m this way. We cannot graduate the odinm which should rest on each class, so accurately, that they will be satisfied for neither class are will ling that any blame should rest upon them. The importer casts the odium upon the re- taller the retailer casts it back upon the importer and "and so they wrap it up.'' The idea of sitting down to discuss the question, whois most to blame? reminds me ofthe anecdote of the two boys, who had worked hard all the day to gain half an hours time for bathing. When they had arrived at the bank of the river, and were prepared to plunge in, it arose, who shall dive first !-Said the younger, "you are older and taller, and better swimmer than l, and you shall dive first. If you succeed in swimming to the shore again, then will .''-No, said the other, s'you shall dive first; and if I find you are like ly to sink, will come to your rescue, and that will be noble deed, every body will tell of it."-There was much to be said on ! nd a{f &hAsr holE hour in discussing the subject, they quietly put on ther clothes again and returned to work.

 Something must be done, and somebo- dy must do it. But if every one looks to his neighbor, insemperance will still deso- late the land, and we shall stih be called nation ,of drunkards. shall not puzzle my brains to ascertain, who is most to blame, the importer, the distiller, the re- tailler, or the druukard; or whe shall stop

 By order of Court,

 PHINEAS CHAPIN, Adm'r. Salisbury, April 16th. 1897. 47

AMEEttG AN nl hAaE EONAG II As

 This grea, National Institution held their anniversary this morning in the Mid de Dutch Church. At o'clock, the Offi- cers, managers, the clergy aud lay dele gates assembled at the SOciety's House, and at halfpast 9 o'clock proceeded in pro- cession to the church.

 At 10 o'clock his excellcncy Governor CLINTON entered, and was conducted to the presidents chair. The Rev. Dr. Day, President of Yale College, commenced the exercise of the day by reading the 7th chapter of Micah. Letters were then read from several of the Vice Presidents apologising for their not being able to att tend the anniversary. Among these was one from the President of the United States, and one from the Hon. John Cot ton Smith, late Governor of Connecticut.

 His excellency Govern lr Clinton then rose and pronounced an address, introduc- tory to the exercises of the day, the deliv- cry of which occupied about eighteen min utes. Unfortunately the crowd was so great that we could not get near enough to hear it. Gentlemen, however, who were more successful, speak of it as one of the most chaste and beautiful productions ot the pen of its eminent author. We shall endeavor to treat our readers with it to- morrow.

 William w. Woolsey, Esq, Treasurer, read his annual report, and the Rev. Mir. Brigham, read the Report of the Man agers. From this highly interesting docu- ment we make the following extracts:

 The receipts of the Society during the year ending lst of May, have amounted to S64,764 13--which is $11,774 19 more than those of the proceeding year. Ot the whole amount, S35, 366 29 were re- ceived in payment for Bibles and Testa- ments, $19,282 82 as free donations. $4,- 225 as subscriptions to pay the debt on the Society's House, and $2,97O as per- manent loans. The particular sources from which the income has been derived, are as follows;

 ments entrusted to individu-

 als in foreign parts, 78O 3l Sales to individuals, 2,893 6 Rents of parts of Bible Society

In conclusion. we have only time Co say, that sae general character Of the speaking ai this celebration, has never been excelled, if II has been equaIled. The audience, HOtwith- standing the untoward state of the weather. was crowded to excess, and the attention Of every one has been enchaincd for hours. Thus may it ever he at these interesting eel chr rations. May their number multiply, their means increase, and their moral influence be extended, until the light of the Gospel shines Ou every mountain, and Eliminates every val lev, from the Atlantic to the Pacific, from Nova Zembla to Cape Horn !!

 ANNIVERSARIES AT HARTFORD.

 During the last week, at the time of the state election, several religious and benev- olent societies held their annual meetings at Hartford, of which the Conn. Observer gives the following account; after saying, that an appropriate sermon was delivered before the Legislature, by Rev. I. Lewis, jr. of Greenwich, from Micah G. 8.

 The anniversaries of the Connecticut Bible Society, and of the Domestic Mis- sionary Society of Connecticut, and the meeting of the General Convention of Connecticut were held on Wednesday. Among other resolutions was one recom- mending that contributions be taken up for the Colonization Society, on the Sab bath proceeding or following the fourth of July. We hope the subject will be at- tended to throug hout the state. The So- ciety is growing in popularity, and in re- sources-and promises to be the medium of unbounded good to the United States as we'll as to Africa.

 The sermon preached before the Do- mestic Missionary Society, was preached on "Wednesday evening by Rev. MT. Ba- con, of New-Haven after which collec- ton of more than $6o was made for the Society.

 On Thursday morning a meeting was held, to consider the expediency of forming a state society auxiliary to tue American Colonization Society.-A statement of the origin, progress and prospects, of this Soci- ety was made by the Agent, Rev. Mir. Gurley and the meeting was addressed by Prof. Hall, Rev. MT. Linsley, s. Ter ry, Esq. & Rev. MT. Goodman, in sup port ofa resolution that it is expedient to form State Colonization Society in Con- necticut. The resolution was passed with great unanimity, and Committee was ap- pointed to report a Constitution for the Society, and to nominate officers, at a sub- sequent meeting.

 On the afternoon of Thursday, meet ing was held by the (" Society for the Im- provement of Common Schools."'

 The Connecticut Sunday School Union held its anniversary in the Centre Church on Thurday evening, when the annual Re- port was read, and several resolutions, supported by able addresses from Rev. C.: A. Boardman, w. w. Ellsworth, Esq. Rev. H. N. Brinsmade, Rev. MT. Car rington, and Rev. Orrin Fowler, were passed.

 By these various meetings, an impulse has been given, we trust, to the cause of truth and benevolence, in the State"

 For the Boston Recor der and Telegraph

 ANOTHER CALL TO ACTION. MEssRs. ED1ToRs,-Ift the community keep on drinking, until they can persuade tins importers of ardent spirits to give up the trade, and the distillers to burn their dis tilleries, fear we shall all become drunkards. The fact is, the importers and distillers will continue the business, as long as the public will keep them in coun- tenance, and no longer. Now if you wish to stop the importation or distillation of ardent spirits, leave off drinking. To be sure, the importer is willing to give up the trade if he can make nothing by it; and the grocer is willing to give up the trade, if there are no ardent spirits imported or distilled and the drunkard, even, will be willing to leave off drinking if he can't get any thing to drink. But which is most to blame, the importer, the distiller, the re- taller, or the tipler? That is the great question. And who shall stop first, is another almost as big. Now let us call our friends together and sat decanters he.

 Messrs. Editors, since last addressed you, volley of Fast day Sermons has been discharged against the common enemy, and not without some effect. Some of the churches in this city, were half awaked, and, trust, that such another volley would bring them to stand upon their feet, and shake themselves from the reproach which has too long rested upon them. Let eve ry professing Christian say for himself, "I have done with ardent spirits" and the work will be half done. Let it no more be said, that such and such minister was seen to call at the bar of tavern, and tip off his glass with as good an air as the worst of us. Let it no more be said, that such and such professor may be good man, for aught we know, but he carries a red nose of his own, and we guess that, with all his religion, he would not stick at glass of brandy o, my brethren, let there be no more occasion for this reproach.  It is worthy of remark, that more than one-flth of the entire income has been re- ceived within the last month and this ac- counts for the fact, that balance remains unexpended; there not having beon time, in tlis short interval, to employ all the means which have been furnished. The Directors express hope that they shall be able to commence the ensuing year on broader scale of operation, and do some- thing more than ever before, towards sup- plying the destitute millions of our fellow men with the word of life.  By this munifcent act the Society is now left in possession of an establishment worth at least S25,OOO; where, without rent, it can carry forward it's sacred work of providing the Scriptures for our own and other lands.

 REUEL COGSWELL, late of Washington, in said district, deceased. represented insolvent; at which time and place all persons interested in said estate will if they see cause, attend before said court and be heard in the premises.

 By order of said court,

 RILEY COGSWELL, Erecutor, Washington, May 12, 1897. 48

Scripture ought tO be prepared with par ticular reference to these Schools; and accor- dingly have directed that a sci of stereotype plates for the entire Bible, and another for the New-Testament, he cast as soon as prac- ticabDe for this important object.

 It will he remembered that a few years since the Society published some portions Ol the New-Testament in the Delaware and Mo- hawk languages. The present Report states that other portions have been translated into the Mohawk tongue by some intelligent AbO- recently forwarded to the Society ny the Rev. Wm. Case, Methodist minister in Lower Canada, and is now in press.

 4 valuable set of 8 vO. stereotype piates' ] with contents of chapters prefxed, has recent l ly been purchased of the Baltimore Bible SO- cietv, to be paid for in Bibles and Testa- ] ments.

 | Bibles issued from the DepOsitory.-During the year, there has been issued from the De- posltory S5, ,G76 Bibles and 8, ,745 Testaments. Total 71,G2l winch added, to 40, ,0l4 issu- ed in the ten proceeding years, make grand total of 51I.667. Of the issue of the last year, 53, 337 have in various ways been dispO- sed of to auxiliary and other Societies and individuals. A still greater number might have been sold, had the rules of the Society permitted sales to those who are not mem bers. The number of Bibles and Testaments gratuitously appropriated during the years, 13.286.

 Comparing these issues with those of the proceeding year, it will be seen that they are greater by 4.487; while the number printed. Is less by 4,266. It IS also observable that the number sold is greater, while the number gratuitously appropriated is less. This last fact is attributed, in the report, to two causes. I. That the Board have during the greater part oflast year, been wholly without trav- cling agents ;-cOnsequently few new Auxll- aries have been formed, to which donations of Bibles are usually made on. recognizing them as connected with the Society. 2. The Managers have hesltated whether more sparing policy in regard to such grants to Auxiliaries, ought rot to be tried. They however express their readiness, at all times when able, to make gratuitous grants where they are truly needed, and where there is known zeal in the Auxiliary to put them in circulation.

 Great complaints are again made of the want ofBibles, in different sections of our county. In one county, in the State of Del aware, 500 families are supposed to be destl- tute in North Carolina, 10000; in South Carolina, perha 3s an equal number; in GeOr- gia, and Teouessee, the same. In short, the whole Southern and Western parts of the Union are in like deplorable situation. The Society has had no travelling Agents during the past year.

 The Rev. Jonas King, late American Mis- si0nary to Palestine, is now in Paris. The Board have requested him to act as delegate of the American Bible Society to that of Pa ris on its ensuing anniversary; and also, if practicable, as Delegate to the British and Foreign Bible Society. ...

 The Report concludes as follows; {" The events of every revolving year indicate that the systems of Pagan corruption and cruelty are ere long to be broken up, and the light and principles of the Gospel to prevade eve ry kindred. and tongue, and people. But be- fore such consummatiOn is realized, much, very much, remains to he done. Not more than forty or fifty million copies of revealed truth, are yet in circulation among the eight hundred millions of the great human family.

 "While then the ultimate uniyersality of the SaviOr's cause is certain as Divine vera city can make it,-whie its onward march is smore and more rapid, (never so much SO perhaps since the ascension of it's Founder as during the past year,) yet it must not he forgotten that this cause is advanced tuTOtiSN uutlldD cuOrtSs anu tndL IncSe eUOrIS must be augmented an hundred fold before the predictions of inspiration are fulfilled. There must yet be a mightier movement on the part of Christendom than has yet been made,-there must be more and greater sa- crifces,--a more entire cOnsecration of time and talents and wealth and inAuence,-and many new helpers must be called into the field; ere this great moral conquest is a. chieved.

 "Lct then the friends of the bible, while inspired by the losses and promises here, un- l folded, go forward and diffuse this blessing at home and abroad, until it is proclaimed throughout every continent and island-that tue Kingdoms of this ,Uorld hGve become tue Kingdoms of fouv Lord and his Christ. After the report the following resolutions 1 were unanimously passed:- On motion of the Rev. Samuel Merwin, of 1 the Methodist Episcopal Church, seconded by the Rev. MT. Smith, of the Episcocopal Church, of MiddIebury, Vt.

 Resolved, That the report which has been presented by the Board of Managers, be ac- cepted, and that it be published under their direction. a"

 On motion of the Rev. MT. Eastburn, of the Episcopal Church, of this city, seconded by the Rev. Mir. Bourne, Baptist Missionary at Honduras, now on a visit to this country for his health,

full articles.headline: { LITCHFlELD COUNTY, ss. } Superior Court, Feb. Term 1897.
full articles.article:
WHEREAS, LAVINA WOODRUFF W of Litchfeld, in said County. has brought her petition to this Court against her husband Salmon Woodruff, now residing in parts to her unknown, therein stating, among other things, that the said Salmon, at said Litchfeld, on or about the first day of July 1928, wilfully deserted her, and ever since has continued, and still continues, his descrton. residing out of this state, in the total neglect of all the duties of the marriage covenant, on his part, to be performed, and praying for a bill of divorce from the said Salmon, as her petition on file, dated the 5th day of Februa- ry 1897. t....

 Ordered by this Court that said petition be continued to the next Term of this Court, to be holden at Litchfield, within and for said County, on the third Tuesday of August next -and that the pendency of said petition, and copy of this order, be published six weeks successively, according to the statute in such case provided, in paper printed in Litchield, called the Litch6eld County Post, and in pa per printed in New-Haven. called the COlsns- bian Register, which shall be sufficient notice to the said Salmon to appear and defend in said petition.

 By the Court.

 F. WOLCOTT, Clerk. A true Copy, 6w4S

 FREDERICK WOLCOTT. Clerk.

full articles.headline: For the Boston Recor der and Telegraph. ANOTHER CALL TO ACTION.
full articles.article:
trade Ii he can make nothing by it; and the grocer is willing to give up the trade, if there are no ardent spirits imported or distilled and the drunkard, even, will be willing to leave off drinking if he can't get any thing to drink. But which is most to blame, the importer, the distiller, the re- taller, or the tipler? That is the great question. And who shall stop first, is another almost as big. Now let us call our friends together, and set decanters be- fore them, and discuss these two moment uous questions. No, Messrs. Editors, we shall never do any thing m this way. We cannot graduate the odinm which should rest on each class, so accurately, that they will be satisfied for neither class are will ling that any blame should rest upon them. The importer casts the odium upon the re- taller the retailer casts it back upon the importer and "and so they wrap it up.'' The idea of sitting down to discuss the question, whois most to blame? reminds me ofthe anecdote of the two boys, who had worked hard all the day to gain half an hours time for bathing. When they had arrived at the bank of the river, and were prepared to plunge in, it arose, who shall dive first !-Said the younger, "you are older and taller, and better swimmer than l, and you shall dive first. If you succeed in swimming to the shore again, then will .''-No, said the other, s'you shall dive first; and if I find you are like ly to sink, will come to your rescue, and that will be noble deed, every body will tell of it."-There was much to be said on ! nd a{f &hAsr holE hour in discussing the subject, they quietly put on ther clothes again and returned to work.

 Something must be done, and somebo- dy must do it. But if every one looks to his neighbor, insemperance will still deso- late the land, and we shall stih be called nation ,of drunkards. shall not puzzle my brains to ascertain, who is most to blame, the importer, the distiller, the re- tailler, or the druukard; or whe shall stop

AMEEttG AN nl hAaE EONAG II As

 This grea, National Institution held their anniversary this morning in the Mid de Dutch Church. At o'clock, the Offi- cers, managers, the clergy aud lay dele gates assembled at the SOciety's House, and at halfpast 9 o'clock proceeded in pro- cession to the church.

 At 10 o'clock his excellcncy Governor CLINTON entered, and was conducted to the presidents chair. The Rev. Dr. Day, President of Yale College, commenced the exercise of the day by reading the 7th chapter of Micah. Letters were then read from several of the Vice Presidents apologising for their not being able to att tend the anniversary. Among these was one from the President of the United States, and one from the Hon. John Cot ton Smith, late Governor of Connecticut.

 His excellency Govern lr Clinton then rose and pronounced an address, introduc- tory to the exercises of the day, the deliv- cry of which occupied about eighteen min utes. Unfortunately the crowd was so great that we could not get near enough to hear it. Gentlemen, however, who were more successful, speak of it as one of the most chaste and beautiful productions ot the pen of its eminent author. We shall endeavor to treat our readers with it to- morrow.

 William w. Woolsey, Esq, Treasurer, read his annual report, and the Rev. Mir. Brigham, read the Report of the Man agers. From this highly interesting docu- ment we make the following extracts:

 The receipts of the Society during the year ending lst of May, have amounted to S64,764 13--which is $11,774 19 more than those of the proceeding year. Ot the whole amount, S35, 366 29 were re- ceived in payment for Bibles and Testa- ments, $19,282 82 as free donations. $4,- 225 as subscriptions to pay the debt on the Society's House, and $2,97O as per- manent loans. The particular sources from which the income has been derived, are as follows;

 May 16, 1897.

In conclusion. we have only time Co say, that sae general character Of the speaking ai this celebration, has never been excelled, if II has been equaIled. The audience, HOtwith- standing the untoward state of the weather. was crowded to excess, and the attention Of every one has been enchaincd for hours. Thus may it ever he at these interesting eel chr rations. May their number multiply, their means increase, and their moral influence be extended, until the light of the Gospel shines Ou every mountain, and Eliminates every val lev, from the Atlantic to the Pacific, from Nova Zembla to Cape Horn !!

 ANNIVERSARIES AT HARTFORD.

 During the last week, at the time of the state election, several religious and benev- olent societies held their annual meetings at Hartford, of which the Conn. Observer gives the following account; after saying, that an appropriate sermon was delivered before the Legislature, by Rev. I. Lewis, jr. of Greenwich, from Micah G. 8.

 The anniversaries of the Connecticut Bible Society, and of the Domestic Mis- sionary Society of Connecticut, and the meeting of the General Convention of Connecticut were held on Wednesday. Among other resolutions was one recom- mending that contributions be taken up for the Colonization Society, on the Sab bath proceeding or following the fourth of July. We hope the subject will be at- tended to throug hout the state. The So- ciety is growing in popularity, and in re- sources-and promises to be the medium of unbounded good to the United States as we'll as to Africa.

 The sermon preached before the Do- mestic Missionary Society, was preached on "Wednesday evening by Rev. MT. Ba- con, of New-Haven after which collec- ton of more than $6o was made for the Society.

 On Thursday morning a meeting was held, to consider the expediency of forming a state society auxiliary to tue American Colonization Society.-A statement of the origin, progress and prospects, of this Soci- ety was made by the Agent, Rev. Mir. Gurley and the meeting was addressed by Prof. Hall, Rev. MT. Linsley, s. Ter ry, Esq. & Rev. MT. Goodman, in sup port ofa resolution that it is expedient to form State Colonization Society in Con- necticut. The resolution was passed with great unanimity, and Committee was ap- pointed to report a Constitution for the Society, and to nominate officers, at a sub- sequent meeting.

 On the afternoon of Thursday, meet ing was held by the (" Society for the Im- provement of Common Schools."'

 The Connecticut Sunday School Union held its anniversary in the Centre Church on Thurday evening, when the annual Re- port was read, and several resolutions, supported by able addresses from Rev. C.: A. Boardman, w. w. Ellsworth, Esq. Rev. H. N. Brinsmade, Rev. MT. Car rington, and Rev. Orrin Fowler, were passed.

 By these various meetings, an impulse has been given, we trust, to the cause of truth and benevolence, in the State"

 For the Boston Recor der and Telegraph

 ANOTHER CALL TO ACTION. MEssRs. ED1ToRs,-Ift the community keep on drinking, until they can persuade tins importers of ardent spirits to give up the trade, and the distillers to burn their dis tilleries, fear we shall all become drunkards. The fact is, the importers and distillers will continue the business, as long as the public will keep them in coun- tenance, and no longer. Now if you wish to stop the importation or distillation of ardent spirits, leave off drinking. To be sure, the importer is willing to give up the trade if he can make nothing by it; and the grocer is willing to give up the trade, if there are no ardent spirits imported or distilled and the drunkard, even, will be willing to leave off drinking if he can't get any thing to drink. But which is most to blame, the importer, the distiller, the re- taller, or the tipler? That is the great question. And who shall stop first, is another almost as big. Now let us call our friends together and sat decanters he.
